title: About
text:
I am a native of Washington, DC, but have spent the past four years basking in the sunny weather of Los Angeles.
I have a strong background in R, having been trained in the Tidyverse packages (although I am firmly of the belief that base R plots are just nicer looking than ggplots) and strong familiarity with working with time series in R. I also have a foundation in Python and can code in C++.
In terms of spoken languages, I can understand Portuguese fluently (and even speak it to an extent), have a decent grasp of Spanish, and a beginner’s level of German (up to the Goethe A2 certificate).
In my — at this point rather limited — free time, I like to run, backpack, and read: I am currently working my way through John Le Carré’s George Smiley series.



Backpacking in Santa Fe

title: Machine Learning Algorithms on Missing Data
text:
I worked with a team of students to model various health measures to try to predict the obesity status of an individual. The data was not clean: it was missing about 8% of the values in each predictor, so we ran 3 separate imputation techniques on it: Amelia (multiple imputation; efficient), mice (multiple imputation; slowish), and missForest (single imputation; very slow — I forgot to have it update me on progress and thought my computer had crashed!).
We then ran several different models on each imputed data set: random forest, logistic regression, KNN, and principal-component discriminant analysis. (The last one was my invention and struggled mightily with this data.) We saw the best results from a random forest model using the missForest-imputed data, which correctly classified all but 5 of the more than 30,000 observations correctly.
If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read our full report here.

title: Advanced Time Series Modelling of Precipitation Rates
text:
I fitted advanced time series models to precipitation totals data at BWI airport. Models used included ARIMA, ARCH, ETS, Holt-Winters, Neural-Net Auto Regression, Prophet, and a somewhat over-optimized combined fit model.
I then forecasted the data 2 years out, showing a dampened version of the trend perceived in the data.

If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read my full report here.

title: Time Series Modelling of Quit Rate
text:
I fitted time series models on BLS data of the monthly number of people leaving a firm out of the total number of people employed by the firm. Using just linear and quadratic seasonally adjusted terms, I manage to capture most of the trends in the data, although the most recent downturn in resignations is not modelled accurately.

If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read my full report here.

title: Taylor Swift Song Popularity
text:
I worked with a team of students to analyze a data set consisting of Spotify streaming data of all of Taylor Swift’s songs, attempting to predict which songs were the most popular and determine the key indicators of popular songs.
We found that songs that were more recent, more acoustic (less electronic), louder, sadder-sounding, shorter, and on a first release album (non-deluxe or Taylor’s Version) were more likely to be popular.
If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read our full report here.

title: Effects of Caffeine on Cognitive and Physical Performance
text:
I worked with a team of students to assess the effects of caffeine on the performance of a group of simulated test subjects from the Islands project.
We conducted several experiments while controlling for confounding effects; although we found no statistically significant results. It was unclear whether our experiment was flawed, caffeine actually has no impact on the functions we tested, or if the Islanders were programmed to not be affected by caffeine in this way.
If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read our full report here.

title: ARIMA Modelling of Surface Temperature
text:
I fitted ARIMA and VAR models onto NOAA data of the global annual change in monthly surface temperature and NASA data of the average ocean surface temperature in a specific region that is highly affected by El Niño. The first model fit the surface temperature data very closely and the second approximated the El Niño data, but can still be improved to capture some of the dynamics.

If you’re interested in reading more about this project, read my full report here.
